text: For the first time since the two nations split,
the leaders of Taiwan and China
will meet face to face.
The historic news broke on Nov. 3:
a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping
and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-Jeou will
take place on Saturday Nov. 7.
Ma's office says the two leaders will
come together in Singapore.
Ma and Xi's meeting will be the first such
interaction of its kind since 1949,
when Taiwan split from China following the
Communist takeover of the mainland.
Beijing still considers Taiwan to be
a breakaway province under its rule;
a huge point of contention between the countries.
So, the upcoming meeting is a major turning point
in relations, no matter what talks will take place.
According to Ma's presidential spokesman,
the Taiwanese leader will reveal more details
about the landmark meeting at an
international news conference on Thursday.
For NewsBeat Social, I'm Molly Riehl.
